text: The Same Fate—Death—Awaits Everyone

So all this I laid to my heart, and I concluded\f + \fr 9:1 \ft Or “examined” \f* that the righteous and the wise, as well as their deeds, \add are\add* in the hand of God. So no one knows anything that will \add come\add* to them, whether \add it will be\add* love or hatred.
The same fate \add comes\add* to everyone:
to the righteous and to the wicked,
to the good and to the wicked,\f + \fr 9:2 \ft Several versions (Greek, Syriac, Latin) insert “and to the bad” \f*
to the clean and to the unclean,
to those who sacrifice and to those who do not sacrifice.
As \add with\add* the good \add man\add*, so also to the sinner;
\add as with\add* those who swear an oath, so \add also\add* those who fear oaths.
This \add is\add* the ⸤injustice⸥\f + \fr 9:3 \ft Literally “evil” \f* that is done under the sun:
the same fate \add comes\add* to everyone.
Also the hearts of ⸤humans⸥\f + \fr 9:3 \ft Literally “the sons of the man” \f* are full \add of\add* evil;
delusion \add is\add* in their hearts during their lives, and then they die.
Death Deprives Humans of Everything in Life

Whoever is joined\f + \fr 9:4 \ft The \fqa Kethib \ft reads “chosen,” but the \fqa Qere \ft as well as all the versions and numerous medieval Hebrew manuscripts read “joined” \f* to all the living has hope. After all, even a live dog is better than a dead lion!
For the living know that they will die, but the dead do not know anything. They no longer have a reward, and even the memory of them is forgotten.
What they loved and hated, as well as what they desired, has already perished. They no longer have any share in what is done under the sun.
Enjoy Life While It Lasts
Go—eat your food with joy, and drink your wine with a merry heart! For God already has approved your deeds.
Always be clothed in white garments, and never let your head lack oil!
Enjoy life with the wife whom you love all the days of your vain life which he gives you under the sun, because this \add is\add* your lot in life and in the toil with which you toil under the sun.
Whatever your hand finds to do—do \add it\add* with \add all\add* your might; for in Sheol—where you are going—no one works, plans, knows, or thinks about anything.
The Injustice of Time and Chance

I looked again and saw under the sun that the race \add does\add* not \add belong\add* to the swift, the battle \add does\add* not \add belong\add* to the mighty, food \add does\add* not \add belong\add* to the wise, wealth \add does\add* not \add belong\add* to the intelligent, and success\f + \fr 9:11 \ft Or “favor” \f* \add does\add* not \add belong\add* to the skillful, for time and chance befalls all of them.

For man does not know his time. Just as fish are caught in a cruel net and like birds who are seized in a snare, so also ⸤humans⸥\f + \fr 9:12 \ft Literally “the sons of the man” \f* are ensnared at a cruel time when it falls suddenly upon them.
Wisdom—Although Vulnerable—is Superior to Power
I have also seen this \add example of\add* wisdom under the sun, and it \add seemed\add* great to me.
\add There was\add* a small city with few people in it. A great king came and besieged it, building great siege works against it.
Now, a poor wise man was found in it, and he delivered the city by his wisdom.
So I concluded that wisdom \add is\add* better than might, yet the wisdom of the poor is despised, and his words are not heard.
Wisdom—Although Vulnerable—is Superior to Folly
The words of the wise are heard in peace
\add more\add* than the shouting of a ruler \add is heard\add* among the fools.
Wisdom \add is\add* better than weapons of war,
but one sinner destroys much good.
